text: The figure $ABCD$ is bounded by a semicircle $CDA$ and a quarter circle $ABC$. Given that the distance from $A$ to $C$ is $18$, find the area of the figure.
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 7
solution:
Y by Adventure10Textual solutionThe area of semicircle $ACD$ is $\frac{1}{2}\pi r^2 = \frac{1}{2}\pi\cdot81 = \frac{81}{2}\pi$



We subtract the area of quarter-circle $ABC$.  To find that, note that $AC$ is a chord (specifically, a chord that is NOT a diameter!) of length $18$ of some circle with center $O$ (which is NOT the midpoint of $AC$).  Also note that $\angle AOC = 90^\circ$.  From that, and the fact that $OA = OC$ because $A$ and $C$ are on circle $O$, we have a $45-45-90$ triangle $AOC$ with hypotenuse $AC$, and thus $OA = OC = \frac{18}{\sqrt{2}} = 9\sqrt{2}$, which is the radius of circle $O$.



We have the radius of the circle, so the area of the whole quarter-sector is $\frac{1}{4}\pi \cdot (9\sqrt{2})^2 = \frac{81}{2}\pi$.  But the area under $ABC$ but above line $AC$ isn't a quarter sector - it's a quarter sector with right triangle cut out.  The right triangle is $AOC$, which has area $\frac{1}{2}AO^2 = \frac{1}{2}\cdot (9\sqrt{2})^2 = 81$.



Thus, the area under $ABC$ but over $AC$ is $\frac{81}{2}\pi - 81$.  We subtract this from $\frac{81}{2}\pi$, the area of the original semicircle we got in the first sentence, to get $\boxed{81}$



Anyone who loves asymptote is welcome to draw a nice diagram.
rewritten_problem: The figure $ABCD$ is bounded by a semicircle $CDA$ and a quarter circle $ABC$. Given that the distance from $A$ to $C$ is $18$, find the area of the figure.

text: Find the least positive integer that has exactly $20$ positive integer divisors.
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 8
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Click to reveal hidden text$20=1 \cdot 20, 2 \cdot 10, 4 \cdot 5$.



Since we know the number of divisors of $n$ is determined by the product of one more than each of the exponents in distinct prime factors, we can conclude that the number $n$ is either $p^{19}$, $p \cdot q^9$, or $p^3 \cdot q^4$. Out of these, the one that will minimize $n$ is $p^3 \cdot q^4$ and by picking $q=2$ and $p=3$



So our answer is $2^4 \cdot 3^3=\boxed{432}$
rewritten_problem: Find the least positive integer that has exactly $20$ positive integer divisors.

text: Bill bought 13 notebooks, 26 pens, and 19 markers for 25 dollars. Paula bought 27 notebooks, 18 pens, and 31 markers for 31 dollars. How many dollars would it cost Greg to buy 24 notebooks, 120 pens, and 52 markers?
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 9
solution:
Y by Adventure10Solution$13N + 26P + 19M = 25$

$27N + 18P + 31M = 31$

$24N + 120P + 52M = ???$



Solving this using linear combinations of the first and second equations should help.

We want to multiply the first equation by $a$ and the second equation by $b$ such that:



$13a + 27b = 24$



$26a + 18b = 120 \rightarrow 13a + 9b = 60$



Hopefully the $M$ column will also work out.  It's not guaranteed other than by the fact that Purple Comet only gives solvable problems.



Subtracting the second equation from the first gives $18b = -36 \rightarrow b =-2$

Plugging in $b=-2$ into either equation gives $13a = 78 \rightarrow a = 6$



This tells us that we want to take $6$ of the first equation, and add it with $-2$ of the second equation.

Doing so gives:

$(13\cdot 6 + 27\cdot -2)N + (26\cdot 6 + 18\cdot -2)P + (19\cdot 6 + 31\cdot -2)M = 25 \cdot 6 + 31\cdot -2$



$24N + 120P + 52M = \boxed{88}$
rewritten_problem: Bill bought 13 notebooks, 26 pens, and 19 markers for 25 dollars. Paula bought 27 notebooks, 18 pens, and 31 markers for 31 dollars. How many dollars would it cost Greg to buy 24 notebooks, 120 pens, and 52 markers?

text: Towers grow at points along a line. All towers start with height 0 and grow at the rate of one meter per second. As soon as any two adjacent towers are each at least 1 meter tall, a new tower begins to grow at a point along the line exactly half way between those two adjacent towers. Before time 0 there are no towers, but at time 0 the first two towers begin to grow at two points along the line. Find the total of all the heights of all towers at time 10 seconds.
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 10
solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionWith the given information, we can say that at time 1, the first two towers reach a height of 1 meter, so one new tower begins to grow. At height 2, the new towers will have grown to a height of 1, so two new towers begin to grow. So each second after, twice as many new towers begin to grow. A tower that begins to grow at time $x$ grows to $10-x$ height by time 10. Thus our answer is $20+ \sum_{x=1}^{9} 2^{k-1}(10-k) = 20+ \sum_{x=1}^{9}(2^k-1) = 9+1024=\boxed{1033}$
rewritten_problem: Towers grow at points along a line. All towers start with height 0 and grow at the rate of one meter per second. As soon as any two adjacent towers are each at least 1 meter tall, a new tower begins to grow at a point along the line exactly half way between those two adjacent towers. Before time 0 there are no towers, but at time 0 the first two towers begin to grow at two points along the line. Find the total of all the heights of all towers at time 10 seconds.

text: The four points $A(-1,2), B(3,-4), C(5,-6),$ and $D(-2,8)$ lie in the coordinate plane. Compute the minimum possible value of $PA + PB + PC + PD$ over all points P .
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 11
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247, and 1 other userClick to reveal hidden textThe minimum value of $PA+PB+PC+PD$ occurs when $P$ is the intersection point of the diagonals $AC$ and $BD$. (This follows from the triangle inequality.)

Now, by the distance formula the length of diagonal $AC$ is $\sqrt{(5-(-1))^2+(-6-2)^2}=10$ and the length of diagonal $BD$ is $\sqrt{(-2-3)^2+(8-(-4))^2}=13$. The answer is $10+13=\boxed{23}$.
rewritten_problem: The four points $A(-1,2), B(3,-4), C(5,-6),$ and $D(-2,8)$ lie in the coordinate plane. Compute the minimum possible value of $PA + PB + PC + PD$ over all points P .

text: What is the least possible sum of two positive integers $a$ and $b$ where $a \cdot b = 10! ?$
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 12
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Solution$10!=10\times9\times8\times7\times6\times5\times4\times3\times2\times1 \Rightarrow 2^8\times3^4\times5^2\times7$



To get the least possible sum, we want $a$ and $b$ to be as small as possible.



Through trial and error, we get $(2^7\times5\times3)(2\times27\times5\times7)=1920\times1890 \Rightarrow 1920+1890=\boxed{3810}$
rewritten_problem: What is the least possible sum of two positive integers $a$ and $b$ where $a \cdot b = 10! ?$

text: Greta is completing an art project. She has twelve sheets of paper: four red, four white, and four blue. She also has twelve paper stars: four red, four white, and four blue. She randomly places one star on each sheet of paper. The probability that no star will be placed on a sheet of paper that is the same color as the star is $\frac{m}{n}$ where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $n - 100m.$
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 13
solution:
Y by Adventure10solOk so we know that the same color star cant match with the same color paper. That means that if we have red sheets of paper they can have only white or blue stars. Similar argument for other colors.

So Lets say we put I don't know $k$ stars that are white on a red sheet of paper. That means we will put $4-k$ blue stars on the red sheet of paper. Since the other white stars need to go on the blue paper we put $4-k$ stars on the blue paper which implies that there will be $k$ stars that are red on the blue paper. This means we have $4-k$ red on the white and $k$ blue on the white. And we have to sum the number of ways this works. But wait!. Note for each color we have a total of $\binom{4}{k}$ ways to arrange. That means for $3$ colors we will have a total of $\binom{4}{k}^3$ ways to arrange where $k$ goes from $0,1...4$ Computing this sum gives $346$. Clearly the denominator is just $\frac{12!}{(4!)^3}!$ because we have 12 pieces of paper and there are 3 groups where in each group 4 are the same color. After doing some heavy simplification we arrive at $\boxed{25}$
rewritten_problem: Greta is completing an art project. She has twelve sheets of paper: four red, four white, and four blue. She also has twelve paper stars: four red, four white, and four blue. She randomly places one star on each sheet of paper. The probability that no star will be placed on a sheet of paper that is the same color as the star is $\frac{m}{n}$ where $m$ and $n$ are relatively prime positive integers. Find $n - 100m.$

text: Let $ABCD$ be a trapezoid with $AB$ parallel to $CD, AB$ has length $1,$ and $CD$ has length $41.$ Let points $X$ and $Y$ lie on sides $AD$ and $BC,$ respectively, such that $XY$ is parallel to $AB$ and $CD,$ and $XY$ has length $31.$ Let $m$ and $n$ be two relatively prime positive integers such that the ratio of the area of $ABYX$ to the area of $CDXY$ is $\tfrac{m}{n}.$ Find $m+2n.$
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 14
solution:
Y by Adventure10 and 1 other userClick to reveal hidden textLet the foot of the perpendicular from $A$ to $\overline{XY}$ be $E$ and the foot of the perpendicular from $E$ to $\overline{DC}$ be $F$. Then $XE=\frac{XY-AB}{2}=\frac{31-1}{2}=15$ and $DF=\frac{DC-AB}{2}=\frac{41-1}{2}=20$.

Note that triangles $AXE$ and $ADF$ are similar with ratio $\frac{DF}{XE}=\frac{20}{15}=\frac{4}{3}$. Let $AE=h$, so by this triangle similarity $AF=\frac{4}{3}h$ and $EF=\frac{4}{3}h-h=\frac{1}{3}h$.

Now, the area of $ABYX$ is $\frac{AB+XY}{2}\cdot h=16h$ and the area of $CDXY$ is $\frac{XY+CD}{2}\cdot \frac{1}{3}h=12h$, and their ratio is $\frac{16h}{12h}=\frac{4}{3}$. The answer $4+2\cdot 3=\boxed{10}$.
rewritten_problem: Let $ABCD$ be a trapezoid with $AB$ parallel to $CD, AB$ has length $1,$ and $CD$ has length $41.$ Let points $X$ and $Y$ lie on sides $AD$ and $BC,$ respectively, such that $XY$ is parallel to $AB$ and $CD,$ and $XY$ has length $31.$ Let $m$ and $n$ be two relatively prime positive integers such that the ratio of the area of $ABYX$ to the area of $CDXY$ is $\tfrac{m}{n}.$ Find $m+2n.$

text: What is the remainder when $7^{8^9}$ is divided by $1000?$
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 15
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionBy Euler's Totient Formula, we know that $7^{400} \equiv 1 \pmod {1000}$. So:



$7^{8^9} \equiv 7^{8^9 \pmod{400}} \equiv 7^{96^2 \cdot 8 \pmod{400}} \equiv 7^{73728 \pmod{400}} \equiv 7^{128} \pmod {1000}$



Darn... Not that easy.



Okay, notice that $7^2=49$ now.



So $7^4 \equiv 401 \pmod {1000}$.



$7^8 \equiv 801 \pmod {1000}$



$7^{16} \equiv 601 \pmod {1000}$



$7^{32} \equiv 201 \pmod {1000}$



$7^{64} \equiv 401 \pmod {1000}$



$7^{128} \equiv \boxed{801} \pmod {1000}$



This is a very nasty problem if you insist on not using the resources you have available to you (i.e. Wolfram Alpha) and just doing it by hand.

This post has been edited 2 times. Last edited by Mrdavid445, Apr 12, 2012, 5:48 PM
Reason: Hid Solution
rewritten_problem: What is the remainder when $7^{8^9}$ is divided by $1000?$

text: Let the complex number $z = \cos\tfrac{1}{1000} + i \sin\tfrac{1}{1000}.$ Find the smallest positive integer $n$ so that $z^n$ has an imaginary part which exceeds $\tfrac{1}{2}.$
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 16
solution:
Y by Adventure10SolutionWrite $z = \text{cis} \frac{1}{1000}$. By De Moivre's Theorem, $z^n = \text{cis} \frac{n}{1000}$ for all $n$.



Now, the smallest positive $n$ satisfying $\Im(z^n) = \sin \frac{n}{1000} > \frac{1}{2}$ must satisfy $\frac{n}{1000} > \frac{\pi}{6}$, or $n > 523.59$. It follows that the smallest $n$ is $\boxed{524}$.
rewritten_problem: Let the complex number $z = \cos\tfrac{1}{1000} + i \sin\tfrac{1}{1000}.$ Find the smallest positive integer $n$ so that $z^n$ has an imaginary part which exceeds $\tfrac{1}{2}.$

by pythogoras $AD = 4sqrt6$

text: If $a$ and $b$ are complex numbers such that $a^2 + b^2 = 5$ and $a^3 + b^3 = 7$, then their sum, $a + b$, is real. The greatest possible value for the sum $a + b$ is $\tfrac{m+\sqrt{n}}{2}$ where $m$ and $n$ are integers. Find $n.$
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 19
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247hello, solving the system

$a^2+b^2=5$

$a^3+b^3=7$

we get in each case for the sum $a+b$

$-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{57}$

or

$-\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{57}$

thus our $n$ is $57$

Sonnhard.

text: A cylinder radius $12$ and a cylinder radius $36$ are held tangent to each other with a tight band. The length of the band is $m\sqrt{k}+n\pi$ where $m$, $k$, and $n$ are positive integers, and $k$ is not divisible by the square of any prime. Find $m + k + n$.
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 21
solution:
Y by Adventure10 and 2 other usersLet the centers of the circles be $A$ and $B$, two of the points of tangency $C$ and $D$, the foot of the perpendicular from $B$ to $\overline{AC}$ be $E$, and the points where $\overline{AB}$ intersects the circles be $F$ and $G$, as shown.



Right triangle $ABE$ has $AB=2AE$, so it is a 30-60-90 triangle, with $\angle EBA=30^\circ$ and $\angle EAB=60^\circ$. Thus $EB=24\sqrt{3}$.

Now notice that $CEBD$ is a rectangle, so $CD=EB=24\sqrt{3}$.

Also, $\angle DBF=180^\circ-30^\circ-90^\circ=60^\circ$, and similarly $\angle CAG=180-60=120^\circ$.

Therefore the length of the band from $GCDF$ is

\[
\frac{120}{360}\cdot 72\pi+24\sqrt{3}+\frac{60}{360}\cdot 24\pi,
\]

and the length of the whole band is twice that, or

\[
2\left(\frac{120}{360}\cdot 72\pi+24\sqrt{3}+\frac{60}{360}\cdot 24\pi\right)=48\sqrt{3}+56\pi.
\]

The answer is $48+3+56=\boxed{107}$.
rewritten_problem: A cylinder radius $12$ and a cylinder radius $36$ are held tangent to each other with a tight band. The length of the band is $m\sqrt{k}+n\pi$ where $m$, $k$, and $n$ are positive integers, and $k$ is not divisible by the square of any prime. Find $m + k + n$.

text: The polynomial $P(x)=a_0+a_1x+a_2x^2+...+a_8x^8+2009x^9$ has the property that $P(\tfrac{1}{k})=\tfrac{1}{k}$ for $k=1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9$.  There are relatively prime positive integers $m$ and $n$ such that $P(\tfrac{1}{10})=\tfrac{m}{n}$.  Find $n-10m$.
title: Purple Comet 2009 HS Problem 25
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Partial solutionLet $Q(x) = x^8(xP(\frac{1}{x}) - 1)=x^9P(\frac{1}{x}) - x^8 = 2009a_9 + a_8x+...+(a_1-1)x^8 + a_0x^9$, so $Q(x)$ is a polynomial of degree $9$ with roots $1,2,3,...,9$.



Therefore, we have that



$Q(x) = a_0(x-1)(x-2)...(x-9) = 2009a_9 + a_8x+...+(a_1-1)x^8 + a_0x^9$,



$\implies Q(10) = 9!a_0 = 10^9P(\frac{1}{10}) - 10^8$



$\implies P(\frac{1}{10}) = \frac{9!a_0}{10^9} + \frac{1}{10}$



Just need to find $a_0$.

text: The Purple Comet! Math Meet runs from April 27 through May 3, so the sum of the calendar dates for these seven days is $27 + 28 + 29 + 30 + 1 + 2 + 3 = 120.$ What is the largest sum of the calendar dates for seven consecutive Fridays occurring at any time in any year?
title: Purple Comet 2009 MS Question 3
solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionWe wish to maximize the sum, so we must include 31 since it is the largest possible day of the month. To maximize the sum of three consecutive Fridays, we add in 17 and 24. Then add in 7, 14, 21, and 28 of the next month to obtain a sum of 142.

text: A train car held $6000$ pounds of mud which was $88$ percent water. Then the train car sat in the sun, and some of the water evaporated so that now the mud is only $82$ percent water. How many pounds does the mud weigh now?
title: Purple Comet 2009 MS Problem 5
solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247Click to reveal hidden textWe know 12% of the mud is not water so there are $60*12=720$ $\text{lbs}$ of non-water mud.  We know now that this makes up 18% of the total amount after the evaporation takes place so if we let $x$ be the total weight we are looking for we have:$\frac{18x}{100}=720$ so $\boxed{x=4000}$

solution: Y by Adventure10Click to reveal hidden textWriting everything as powers of 2 and 5, we get $2^{4018}\cdot 5^{2009}=2^{2000}\cdot 5^{2000}\cdot 2^{27}\cdot 5^9\cdot 2^n$. The powers of 5 cancel, and we find $n=\boxed{1991}$.

text: How many distinct four letter arrangements can be formed by rearranging the letters found in the word FLUFFY? For example, FLYF and ULFY are two possible arrangements.
title: Purple Comet 2009 MS Problem 7
solution:
Y by Adventure10Click to reveal hidden textThe letters we can use are FFFLUY.



Case 1: 1 F The rest of the letters must be LUY, and there are $4!=24$ ways to arrange these letters.



Case 2: 2 F's There are $\binom{3}{2}=3$ ways to choose the rest of the letters, and each choice of letters can be arranged in $\frac{4!}{2!}=12$ ways. So we have $3\cdot 12=36$ words in this case.



Case 3: 3 F's The last letter must be either L, U, or Y, and then we can arrange the letters in $\frac{4!}{3!}=4$ ways. So we have $3\cdot 4=12$ words in this case.





Adding up, we see that the answer is $24+36+12=\boxed{72}$.
rewritten_problem: How many distinct four letter arrangements can be formed by rearranging the letters found in the word FLUFFY? For example, FLYF and ULFY are two possible arrangements.

text: Find the number of non-congruent scalene triangles whose sides all have integral length, and the longest side has length $11$.
title: Purple Comet 2009 MS Problem 8
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Not sure if this is right...Let $a<b<11$ be the lengths of the remaining two sides. From the triangle inequality, we know that in order for there to be a triangle with lengths $a$, $b$, $11$, we must have $a+b>11$. The possibilities for $a$ and $b$ are:

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
a&b\\ \hline
2& 10\\
3& 9, 10\\
4&8,9,10\\
5&7,8,9,10\\
6&7,8,9,10\\
7&8,9,10\\
8&9,10\\
9&10
\end{array}
\]

In total, there are $1+2+3+4+4+3+2+1=\boxed{20}$ triangles that satisfy the problem.
rewritten_problem: Find the number of non-congruent scalene triangles whose sides all have integral length, and the longest side has length $11$.

text: One plant is now $44$ centimeters tall and will grow at a rate of $3$ centimeters every $2$ years. A second plant is now $80$ centimeters tall and will grow at a rate of $5$ centimeters every $6$ years. In how many years will the plants be the same height?
title: Purple Comet 2009 MS Problem 9
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247, and 1 other userRobotic but easily understandable wayThe height of the first plant is given by $h_1(t) = 44 + \frac{3}{2}t$, where $h_1(t)$ is the height (in centimeters), and $t$ is the time after now (in years).  Note that $h_1(0) = 44$ and $h_1(2) = 47$, which makes sense, and since the growth is linear, this must be the right function.



Similarly, $h_2(t) = 80 + \frac{5}{6}t$.  We set $h_1(t) = h_2(t)$ to find the time when both plants are at the same height.



$44 + \frac{3}{2}t = 80 + \frac{5}{6}t$



$\left(\frac{3}{2} - \frac{5}{6}\right)t = 80 - 44$



$\frac{2}{3}t = 36$



$t = \frac{3}{2}\cdot 36$



$t = \boxed{54}$ years.



Fast but error-prone wayAn alternate way to think of the problem (which actually involves similar math, but avoids some fractions) is that in $6$ years, the first plant grows $3 \cdot 3 = 9$ centimeters, while the second plant grows $5$ centimeters.  Thus, the shorter plant "gains" $9 - 5 = 4$ centimeters on the taller plant in $6$ years.  The plant needs to gain a total of $80 - 44 = 36$ centimeters, so it will take $\frac{36}{4} = 9$ "bundles" of $6$ years, for a total of $\boxed{54}$ years.



Check your work, and/or answering another question that could have been askedAs a sanity check, in $54$ years, the first plant has grown $3 \cdot \frac{54}{2} = 81$ centimeters, and is $44 + 81 = 125$ centimeters tall.  The second plant has grown $5 \cdot \frac{54}{6} = 45$ centimeters, and is now $45 + 80 = 125$ centimeters tall.
rewritten_problem: One plant is now $44$ centimeters tall and will grow at a rate of $3$ centimeters every $2$ years. A second plant is now $80$ centimeters tall and will grow at a rate of $5$ centimeters every $6$ years. In how many years will the plants be the same height?

text: Aisha went shopping. At the first store she spent $40$ percent of her money plus four dollars. At the second store she spent $50$ percent of her remaining money plus $5$ dollars. At the third store she spent $60$ percent of her remaining money plus six dollars. When Aisha was done shopping at the three stores, she had two dollars left. How many dollars did she have with her when she started shopping?
title: Purple Comet 2009 MS Problem 11
solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247Click to reveal hidden textWe work backwards. Let the amount of money before entering the third store be $x$. Then $x-(0.6x+6)=2$, so $x=\frac{2+6}{1-0.6}=20$ dollars. Similarly, the amount of money before entering the second store is $\frac{20+5}{1-0.5}=50$ dollars and the amount of money before entering the first store is $\frac{50+4}{1-0.4}=\boxed{90}$ dollars.

How many dollars did she have with her when she started shopping?

text: How many subsets of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 12\}$ contain exactly one or two prime numbers?
title: Purple Comet 2009 MS Problem 13
solution:
Y by Adventure10Click to reveal hidden textThere are 5 primes in the set: $2,3,5,7,11$. There are $5$ ways to choose one prime and $\binom{5}{2}=10$ ways to choose $2$ primes.



Then of the 7 non-primes, we can choose a subset in $2^7=128$ ways.



So, the total number of subsets that contain exactly one or two prime numbers is $5\cdot 128+10\cdot 128=15\cdot 128=\boxed{1920}$.
rewritten_problem: How many subsets of the set $\{1, 2, 3, \ldots, 12\}$ contain exactly one or two prime numbers?

title: Purple Comet 2008 MS Problem 1

Prime factoring 186, we have:

\[186=2\cdot3\cdot\boxed{31}\]

text: Starting on April 15, 2008, you can go one day backward and one day forwards to get the dates 14 and 16. If you go 15 days backward and 15 days forward, you get the dates 31 (from March) and 30 (from April). Find the least positive integer k so that if you go k days backward and k days forward you get two calendar dates that are the same.
title: Purple Comet 2008 MS Problem 2
solution: Y by Adventure10SolutionThe two dates must be in different months, so we are looking for the month with the fewest number of days, which is February. If you go 14 days forward and backward from February 15 (in a non-leap year), you get February 1 and March 1, so the least possible $k$ is 14.

Women = $405*1.2=$ $\boxed{486}$

text: While driving his car, Ken pulled off the road to get gasoline when he was of $\frac{7}{12}$ the way through his trip. After driving another eleven miles, he noticed that he was $\frac{13}{20}$ of the way through his trip. How many miles long was his entire trip?
title: Purple Comet 2008 MS Problem 4
solution:
Y by Adventure10SolutionLet the distance be $d$.



$\dfrac{13}{20}d-11=\dfrac{7}{12}d$



$\dfrac{13}{20}d-\dfrac{7}{12}d=11$



$\dfrac{39}{60}d-\dfrac{35}{60}d=11$



$\dfrac{4}{60}d=11$



$\dfrac{15}{1}\cdot\dfrac{1}{15}d=11\cdot\dfrac{15}{1}$



$d=\boxed{165}$
rewritten_problem: While driving his car, Ken pulled off the road to get gasoline when he was of $\frac{7}{12}$ the way through his trip. After driving another eleven miles, he noticed that he was $\frac{13}{20}$ of the way through his trip. How many miles long was his entire trip?

text: What is the measurement in degrees of the angle formed by the minute and hour hands when a clock reads $12:12$?
title: Purple Comet 2008 MS Problem 5
solution: Y by Adventure10SolutionWell, we have the hour hand 1/5 the way between 12 and 1, and the minute hand 1/5 of the way around the clock.  We have the minute hand at 72 degrees past 12, and the hour hand only 6 degrees past 12.  Thus, the distance between them is $72-6=\boxed{66^{\circ}}$
rewritten_problem: What is the measurement in degrees of the angle formed by the minute and hour hands when a clock reads $12:12$?

text: The product of two positive numbers is equal to $50$ times their sum and $75$ times their difference.  Find their sum.
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 6
solution:
Y by Adventure10SolutionWe have

\[mn=50(m+n)\]

\[mn=75(m-n)\]

Multiplying the top by 3, and the bottom 2:

\[3mn=150m+150n\]

\[2mn=150m-150n\]

Canceling:

\[5mn=300m\]

Dividing:

\[n=60\]

Substituting,

\[120m=150m-9000\]

\[30m=9000\]

\[m=300\]

\[m+n=\boxed{360}\]
rewritten_problem: The product of two positive numbers is equal to $50$ times their sum and $75$ times their difference.  Find their sum.

text: The diagram below shows an isosceles triangle with base $21$ and height $28$.  Inscribed in the triangle is a square.  Find the area of the shaded region inside the triangle and outside of the square.
title: Purple Comet 2008 MS Problem 7
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247solNotice that our top shaded triangle is similar to the entire triangle. Let $s$ be the sidelength of the square

We have $\frac{4}{3}=\frac{28-x}{x}$. Solving we have $x=12$

We seek $(21)(14)-144=\boxed{150}$
rewritten_problem: The diagram below shows an isosceles triangle with base $21$ and height $28$.  Inscribed in the triangle is a square.  Find the area of the shaded region inside the triangle and outside of the square.

text: At Mallard High School there are three intermural sports leagues: football, basketball, and baseball.  There are 427 students participating in these sports: 128 play on football teams, 291 play on basketball teams, and 318 play on baseball teams.  If exactly 36 students participate in all three of the sports, how many students participate in exactly two of the sports?
title: Purple Comet 2008 MS Problem 8
solution:
Let $x$ be the number of students participating in exactly $2$ of the sports. This is straight up PIE.

$$427=128+291+318-x+36$$$$427=773-x$$$$x=773-427=\boxed{346}$$
rewritten_problem: At Mallard High School there are three intermural sports leagues: football, basketball, and baseball.  There are 427 students participating in these sports: 128 play on football teams, 291 play on basketball teams, and 318 play on baseball teams.  If exactly 36 students participate in all three of the sports, how many students participate in exactly two of the sports?

text:
A city is laid out with a rectangular grid of roads with 10 streets numbered from 1 to 10 running east-west and 16 avenues numbered from 1 to 16 running northsouth.  All streets end at First and Sixteenth Avenues, and all avenues end at First and Tenth Streets.  A rectangular city park is bounded on the north and south by Sixth Street and Eighth Street, and bounded on the east and west by Fourth Avenue and Twelfth Avenue. Although there are no breaks in the roads that bound the park, no road goes through the park.  The city paints a crosswalk from every street corner across any adjacent road.  Thus, where two roads cross such as at Second Street and Second Avenue, there are four crosswalks painted, while at corners such as First Street and First Avenue, there are only two crosswalks painted.

How many crosswalks are there painted on the roads of this city?

text: Let $A_1A_2A_3...A_{12}$ be a regular dodecagon. Find the number of right triangles whose vertices are in the set ${A_1A_2A_3...A_{12}}$
title: Purple Comet 2008 MS Problem 13
solution: Y by Saw a similar problem recently...We inscribe $A_1A_2A_3...A_{12}$ into a circle. Then we see that there are $6$ diameters and each diameter can create $10$ right triangles with the remaining $10$ points. Thus our answer is $6*10=\boxed{60}.$
rewritten_problem: Let $A_1A_2A_3...A_{12}$ be a regular dodecagon. Find the number of right triangles whose vertices are in the set ${A_1A_2A_3...A_{12}}$

text: Ralph is standing along a road which heads straight east.  If you go nine miles east, make a left turn, and travel seven miles north, you will find Pamela with her mountain bike.  At exactly the same time that Ralph begins running eastward along the road at 6 miles per hour, Pamela begins biking in a straight line at 10 miles per hour.  Pamelas direction is chosen so that she will reach a point on the road where Ralph is running at exactly the same time Ralph reaches that same point.   Let $M$ and $N$ be relatively prime positive integers such that $\frac{M}{N}$ is the number of hours that it takes Pamela and Ralph to meet. Find $M+N$.
title: Purple Comet 2008 MS Problem 14
solution:
Let us call Ralph's starting point $A$

Let us call Pamela's starting point $B$

Let us call where Ralph and Pamela meet as $C$

Let x be the distance from where the perpendicular of $B$ hits line $AC$ to point $C.$

Since Pamela moves faster than Ralph that means that they will meet somewhere between 9 miles east of Ralph's starting point and Ralph's starting point. Thus, we can create a system of equations using pythagorean theorem and rates.

$$\frac{\sqrt{49+x^2}}{10}=\frac{9-x}{6}$$$$6\sqrt{49+x^2}=90-10x$$$$-64x^2+1800x-6336=0$$$$-8(x-24)(8x-33)=0$$Thus $x=24$ or $x=\frac{3}{8}.$

Since $x$ has to be less than $9$ the length is $\frac{33}{8}$

Thus the number of hours it takes is $(9-\frac{33}{8})*\frac{1}{6}=\frac{39}{8}*\frac{1}{6}=\frac{13}{16}.$

Our answer is $13+16=\boxed{29}$
rewritten_problem: Ralph is standing along a road which heads straight east.  If you go nine miles east, make a left turn, and travel seven miles north, you will find Pamela with her mountain bike.  At exactly the same time that Ralph begins running eastward along the road at 6 miles per hour, Pamela begins biking in a straight line at 10 miles per hour.  Pamelas direction is chosen so that she will reach a point on the road where Ralph is running at exactly the same time Ralph reaches that same point.   Let $M$ and $N$ be relatively prime positive integers such that $\frac{M}{N}$ is the number of hours that it takes Pamela and Ralph to meet. Find $M+N$.

text: What is the least positive integer with the property that the product of its digits is $9! ?$
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 1
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Solution$9!=2^7*3^4*5*7$



We have $2$ digits of $9$



We can also have $2$ digits of $8$



We can also have $1$ digit of $2$



$1$ digit of $5$



$1$ digit of $7$



We want the smallest to largest, so our number would be $\boxed{2578899}$
rewritten_problem: What is the least positive integer with the property that the product of its digits is $9! ?$

text: A canister contains two and a half cups of flour.  Greg and Sally have a brownie recipe which calls for one and one third cups of flour.  Greg and Sally want to make one and a half recipes of brownies.  To the nearest whole percent, what percent of the flour in the canister would they use?
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 2
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionThey total of $2.5$ cups total.



One recipe requires $4/3$ cups.



$(4/3)*(3/2)=2$



They use $2/2.5=20/25=4/5=$ $\boxed{80}$
rewritten_problem: A canister contains two and a half cups of flour.  Greg and Sally have a brownie recipe which calls for one and one third cups of flour.  Greg and Sally want to make one and a half recipes of brownies.  To the nearest whole percent, what percent of the flour in the canister would they use?

text: Find the least integer  $n$ greater than $345$ such that $\frac{3n+4}{5},  \frac{4n+5}{3},$ and $\frac{5n+3}{4}$ are all integers.
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 3
solution:
Y by Adventure10solutionFrom the first fraction we have

$ 3n+4\equiv 0(\mod 5)\implies $

$ 3n\equiv-4(\mod 5)\implies $

$ 3n\equiv1(\mod 5)\implies $

$ n\equiv2(\mod 5) $.



From the second fraction we have

$ 4n+5\equiv0(\mod 3)\implies $

$ 4n\equiv-5(\mod 3)\implies $

$ 4n\equiv1(\mod 3)\implies $

$ n\equiv1(\mod 3) $.



And from the third fraction we have

$ 5n+3\equiv0(\mod 4)\implies $

$ 5n\equiv-3(\mod 4)\implies $

$ 5n\equiv1(\mod 4)\implies $

$ n\equiv1(\mod 4) $.



We therefore have:

$ n\equiv2(\mod 5) $

$ n\equiv1(\mod 3) $

$ n\equiv1(\mod 4) $.



The last two imply that $ n\equiv1(\mod 12) $, so we have

$ n\equiv2(\mod 5) $

$ n\equiv1(\mod 12) $.



Now for some number sense. The second modular equation implies that $ n $ is odd, and the first implies that $ n $ has a units digit of $ 2 $ or $ 7 $. Since $ n $ is odd, it must have a units digit of $ 7 $. Now we've narrowed it down enough to begin testing numbers ending in $ 7 $, whether or not $ n-1 $ is divisible by $ 12 $.

$ 347-1=346 $ isn't divisible by $ 3 $.

$ 357-1=356 $ isn't divisible by $ 3 $.

$ 367-1=366 $ is divisible by $ 3 $ but not by $ 4 $.

$ 377-1=376 $ isn't divisible by $ 3 $.

$ 387-1=386 $ isn't divisible by $ 3 $.

$ 397-1=396 $ is divisible by $ 12 $.

So, the smallest $ n $ such that the given fractions are integers is $ n=\boxed{397} $.
rewritten_problem: Find the least integer  $n$ greater than $345$ such that $\frac{3n+4}{5},  \frac{4n+5}{3},$ and $\frac{5n+3}{4}$ are all integers.

text: The student population at one high school consists of freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors.  There are 25 percent more freshmen than juniors, 10 percent fewer sophomores than freshmen, and 20 percent of the students are seniors. If there are 144 sophomores, how many students attend the school?
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 4
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionSince there are $144$ sophomores, there are $144/0.9=160$ freshman.



There are $160*0.75=120$ juniors.



$120+160+144=424$ freshmen, sophomores, and juniors.



Since $424=0.8x$, $x=$ $\boxed{530}$
rewritten_problem: The student population at one high school consists of freshmen, sophomores, juniors, and seniors.  There are 25 percent more freshmen than juniors, 10 percent fewer sophomores than freshmen, and 20 percent of the students are seniors. If there are 144 sophomores, how many students attend the school?

text: Find the sum of all the digits in the decimal representations of all the positive integers less than $1000.$
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 5
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionThe sum will remain the same if we include leading zeros and if we add the number $0$ itself, so we count from $000$ to $999$.



The units digit will go from $0$ to $9$, and then reset to $0$.  This gives a sum of $45$ for the first ten units digits.

This will repeat a total of $\frac{1000}{10} = 100$ times until we hit $999$.  That means the units digits will sum to $45\cdot 100 = 4500$.



By symmetry, the tens digit and hundreds digit will have the same sum.  The order may be different, but all the digits are the same if you rearrange them.  Therefore, the total sum is $4500\cdot 3 = \boxed{13500}$.
rewritten_problem: Find the sum of all the digits in the decimal representations of all the positive integers less than $1000.$

text: Three friends who live in the same apartment building leave the building at the same time to go rock climbing on a cliff just outside of town.  Susan walks to the cliff and climbs to the top of the cliff.  Fred runs to the cliff twice as fast as Susan walks and climbs the top of the cliff at a rate that is only two-thirds as fast as Susan climbs.  Ralph bikes to the cliff at a speed twice as fast as Fred runs and takes two hours longer to climb to the top of the cliff than Susan does.  If all three friends reach the top of the cliff at the same time, how many minutes after they left home is that?
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 6
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionLet $F_w, F_c, S_w, S_c, R_w,$ and $R_c$ represent the time each person spends "on foot" and climbing, in hours.



$F_w = \frac{S_w}{2}$ (Fred runs to the cliff twice as fast as Susan walks)



$F_c = \frac{3S_c}{2}$ (Fred climbs the top of the cliff at a rate that is only two-thirds as fast as Susan climbs)



$R_w = \frac{F_w}{2}$ (Ralph bikes to the cliff at a speed twice as fast as Fred runs)



$R_c = S_c + 2$ (Ralph takes two hours longer to climb to the top of the cliff than Susan does)



The first three equations reprsent the inverse relationship that rate and time have when distance is held constant.



Since all three reach the top at the same time, we have:



$F_w + F_c = R_w + R_c = S_w + S_c$



Let's take the first and third parts of that equation:

$F_w + F_c = S_w + S_c$



$\frac{S_w}{2} + \frac{3S_s}{2} = S_w + S_c$



$S_w = S_c$



Now let's take the first and second parts of that equation:

$F_w + F_c = R_w + R_c$



$\frac{S_w}{2} + \frac{3S_c}{2} = \frac{F_w}{2} + S_c + 2$



Using $S_w = S_c$ and $F_w = 0.5\cdot S_w$:

$\frac{S_c}{2} + \frac{3S_c}{2} = \frac{S_w}{4} + S_c + 2$



$2S_c = \frac{5S_c}{4} + 2$



$\frac{3S_c}{4} = 2$



$S_c = \frac{8}{3} = S_w$



$S_c + S_w = \frac{16}{3}$ hours, so the total trip took $\boxed{330}$ minutes.
rewritten_problem: Three friends who live in the same apartment building leave the building at the same time to go rock climbing on a cliff just outside of town.  Susan walks to the cliff and climbs to the top of the cliff.  Fred runs to the cliff twice as fast as Susan walks and climbs the top of the cliff at a rate that is only two-thirds as fast as Susan climbs.  Ralph bikes to the cliff at a speed twice as fast as Fred runs and takes two hours longer to climb to the top of the cliff than Susan does.  If all three friends reach the top of the cliff at the same time, how many minutes after they left home is that?

text: A line through the origin passes through the curve whose equation is $5y=2x^2-9x+10$ at two points whose $x-$coordinates add up to $77.$  Find the slope of the line.
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 7
solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247solutionLet $ y=kx $ be the line through the origin, where $ k $ is the slope. Plugging this in to the given equation of the parabola, we have $ 5kx=2x^2-9x+10 $, or $ 2x^2-(9+5k)x+10=0 $. By Vieta, the sum of the solutions, which are the x-coordinates, is $ \frac{9+5k}{2} $. However, we are given that the sum of the x-coordinates is $ 77 $, so we have $ \frac{9+5k}{2}=77 $, or $ k=\boxed{29} $.
rewritten_problem: A line through the origin passes through the curve whose equation is $5y=2x^2-9x+10$ at two points whose $x-$coordinates add up to $77.$  Find the slope of the line.

text: A container is shaped like a square-based pyramid where the base has side length $23$ centimeters and the height is $120$ centimeters. The container is open at the base of the pyramid and stands in an open field with its vertex pointing down. One afternoon $5$ centimeters of rain falls in the open field partially filling the previously empty container. Find the depth in centimeters of the rainwater in the bottom of the container after the rain.
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 8
solution:
Y by Adventure10SolutionWhen it is claimed that "five centimeters of rain fell", it is assumed that this means that if you measure an area $A$, then a volume of $5A$ of rain fell within that area.



Rain is collected from the area of $23\cdot 23 = 529$ square centimeters that are open at the base.  Thus, we are talking about a volume of $529 \cdot 5 = 2645$ cubic centimeters.  This rain is "funneled" into the pyramid.



Now we draw a smaller, similar pyramid that represents the amount of rain collected.  The base will have an area of $\frac{23}{x}\frac{23}{x} = \frac{529}{x^2}$, while the height will be $\frac{120}{x}$, where $x$ is the "shrinking constant".



The volume of this pyramid is $\frac{1}{3}Bh = \frac{1}{3}\cdot\frac{529}{x^2}\cdot\frac{120}{x} = \frac{21160}{x^3}$.

Set that volume equal to the $2645$ cubic centimeters that have been funneled into the pyramid:



$2645 = \frac{21160}{x^3}$



$x^3 = \frac{21160}{2645}$



$x^3 = 8$

$x = 2$



The height of this container is $\frac{120}{2} = \boxed{60}$
rewritten_problem: A container is shaped like a square-based pyramid where the base has side length $23$ centimeters and the height is $120$ centimeters. The container is open at the base of the pyramid and stands in an open field with its vertex pointing down. One afternoon $5$ centimeters of rain falls in the open field partially filling the previously empty container. Find the depth in centimeters of the rainwater in the bottom of the container after the rain.

text: Find the sum of all the integers  $N  >  1$  with the properties that the each prime factor of  $N $ is either  $2, 3,$ or $5,$ and  $N$  is not divisible by any perfect cube greater than $1.$
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 9
solution: Y by Adventure10solutionAll numbers satisfying this are of the form $ 2^a\times3^b\times5^c $, where $ a,b, $ and $ c $ are whole numbers less than $ 3 $. Notice that all of these numbers are factors of the number $ 2^2\times3^2\times5^2 $. Thus, the sum of all of these numbers is equal to the sum of the factors of $ 2^2\times3^2\times5^2 $ minus $ 1 $, since we don't want to count $ 1 $. The sum of these factors is $ (2^2+2+1)(3^2+3+1)(5^2+5+1) $, since when multiplying this out, all factors are accounted for. Simplifying this we get $ 2821 $, and subtracting $ 1 $ yields $ \boxed{2820} $.
rewritten_problem: Find the sum of all the integers  $N  >  1$  with the properties that the each prime factor of  $N $ is either  $2, 3,$ or $5,$ and  $N$  is not divisible by any perfect cube greater than $1.$

text: There are three men and eleven women taking a dance class.  In how many different ways can each man be paired with a woman partner and then have the eight remaining women be paired into four pairs of two?
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 10
solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionThere are $11 \times 10 \times 9=990$ ways to pair up three women with the three men. Then there are $\binom{8}{2} \times \binom{6}{2} \times \binom{4}{2}$ ways to choose the four pairs in order, but we must divide this by $4!=24$ since the order in which we choose the pairs does not matter. The total number of ways to form the groups is then $990 \times \frac{28 \times 15 \times 6}{24}=\boxed{103950}$.
rewritten_problem: There are three men and eleven women taking a dance class.  In how many different ways can each man be paired with a woman partner and then have the eight remaining women be paired into four pairs of two?

text: Six regular octagons each with sides of length 2 are placed in a two-by-three array and inscribed in a square as shown. The area of the square can be written in the form $m+n\sqrt{2}$ where $m$ and $n$ are positive integers. Find $m+n$.
title: Problem 11 2008 High School
solution:
Y by Adventure10179

The answer is 179.
rewritten_problem: Six regular octagons each with sides of length 2 are placed in a two-by-three array and inscribed in a square as shown. The area of the square can be written in the form $m+n\sqrt{2}$ where $m$ and $n$ are positive integers. Find $m+n$.

text: We record one number every workday: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday.  On the first Monday the number we record is ten and a half.  On every Tuesday and every Thursday the number we record is one third of what it was on the previous workday.  On every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday the number we record is double what it was on the previous workday.  This will go on forever. What is the sum of all of the numbers we will record?
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 12
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Click to reveal hidden textIf the number recorded on the first Monday is $n$, then in the first week we have $n,{n\over 3},{2n\over 3},{2n\over 9},{4n\over 9}$, and the next week starts with ${8n\over 9}$.



Thus $S=\frac{n+{n\over 3}+{2n\over 3}+{2n\over 9}+{4n\over 9}}{1-{8\over 9}}=24n=252$
rewritten_problem: We record one number every workday: Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday.  On the first Monday the number we record is ten and a half.  On every Tuesday and every Thursday the number we record is one third of what it was on the previous workday.  On every Monday, Wednesday, and Friday the number we record is double what it was on the previous workday.  This will go on forever. What is the sum of all of the numbers we will record?

text: If you roll six fair dice, let $\mathsf{ p}$ be the probability that exactly five different numbers appear on the upper faces of the six dice.  If  $\mathsf{p} = \frac{m}{n}$ where $ m $ and  $n$ are relatively prime positive integers, find $m+n.$
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 13
solution: Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionWe choose 5 numbers to appear, so 6 ways.  Now we choose 1 of the numbers to appear twice, so 5 ways.  Finally, we must multiply by $\tfrac{7!}{2}$ because two of the numbers are indistinguishable.  The denominator is $6^6$, so the fraction is $\tfrac{360 \cdot 6 \cdot 5}{6^6}$, or $\tfrac{25}{108}$.  Hence the answer is $\boxed{133}$.
rewritten_problem: If you roll six fair dice, let $\mathsf{ p}$ be the probability that exactly five different numbers appear on the upper faces of the six dice.  If  $\mathsf{p} = \frac{m}{n}$ where $ m $ and  $n$ are relatively prime positive integers, find $m+n.$

text: A circular track with diameter $500$ is externally tangent at a point A to a second circular track with diameter $1700.$  Two runners start at point A at the same time and run at the same speed.  The first runner runs clockwise along the smaller track while the second runner runs clockwise along the larger track.  There is a first time after they begin running when their two positions are collinear with the point A.  At that time each runner will have run a distance of $\frac{m\pi}{n}$ where  $m$  and  $n$ are relatively prime positive integers.  Find  $m + n. $
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 14
solution:
Let us call the $2$ points where the runners stop as $B$ and $C$ and the center of the small circle and big circle $D$ and $E$ respectively. If we draw $DA, DB, EA,EC$ we see that $\angle DBA = \angle DAB = \angle EAC = \angle ECA$ and $\angle ADB = \angle AEC.$ Let us call the distance that each runner runs as $x.$ Then we see that since $\angle ADB = \angle AEC,$ that their distance divided by the diameter should be equal.

$$\frac{x}{1700}=\frac{x}{500}$$$$x=0$$Well $x \neq 0$ so we try the next case which is where the runner on the small track completes a revolution and then the runners meet.

$$\frac{x}{1700}=\frac{x-500}{500}$$$$x=\frac{2125}{3}$$$$2125+3=\boxed{2128}$$
rewritten_problem: A circular track with diameter $500$ is externally tangent at a point A to a second circular track with diameter $1700.$  Two runners start at point A at the same time and run at the same speed.  The first runner runs clockwise along the smaller track while the second runner runs clockwise along the larger track.  There is a first time after they begin running when their two positions are collinear with the point A.  At that time each runner will have run a distance of $\frac{m\pi}{n}$ where  $m$  and  $n$ are relatively prime positive integers.  Find  $m + n. $

text:
For natural number $n$, define the function $f(n)$ to be the number you get by $f(n)$ adding the digits of the number $n$. For example, $f(16)=7$, $f(f(78))=6$, and $f(f(f(5978)))=2$.

Find the least natural number $n$ such that $f(f(f(n)))$ is not a one-digit number.
title: 2008 High School Problem 15
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Click to reveal hidden textIf you keep working backwards from 10, you get

$\min f(f(f(n)))=10\implies \min f(f(n))=19\implies \min f(n)=199\implies \min n=19999999999999999999999$

Hello, yes, the result is very large.

text: Square ABCD has side length 7.  Let $A_1$, $B_1$, $C_1$, and $D_1$ be points on rays $\overrightarrow{AB}$, $\overrightarrow{BC}$, $\overrightarrow{CD}$, and $\overrightarrow{DA}$, respectively, where each point is $3$ units from the end of the ray so that $A_1B_1C_1D_1$ forms a second square as shown.  SImilarly, let $A_2$, $B_2$, $C_2$, and $D_2$ be points on segments $A_1B_1$, $B_1C_1$, $C_1D_1$, and $D_1A_1$, respectively, forming another square where $A_2$ divides segment $A_1B_1$ into two pieces whose lengths are in the same ratio as $AA_1$ is to $A_1B$.  Continue this process to construct square $A_nB_nC_nD_n$ for each positive integer $n$.  Find the total of all the perimeters of all the squares.

solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Click to reveal hidden textFirst, we find the length of $A_1B_1$ to be 5.  Now, because each square splits the previous one in the same proportion, this can be seen as an infinite geometric series with common ratio $\frac{5}{7}$ with $a_1=28$.



$S=\frac{28}{1-\frac{5}{7}}=98$

text: One side of a triangle has length $75$.  Of the other two sides, the length of one is double the length of the other.  What is the maximum possible area for this triangle
title: 2008 High School #19
solution:
Y by Adventure10 and 3 other usershello, let $x,2x,75$ the side-lengths of the given triangle, then we get by the Heronian formula

$A=\sqrt { \left( 3/2\,x+{\frac {75}{2}} \right)  \left( 3/2\,x-{\frac {
75}{2}} \right)  \left( 1/2\,x+{\frac {75}{2}} \right)  \left( -1/2\,x
+{\frac {75}{2}} \right) }
$

differentiating this with respect to $x$ and simplifying we get

$A'(x)=-3/2\,{\frac {x \left( {x}^{2}-3125 \right) }{\sqrt {- \left( x+25
 \right)  \left( x-25 \right)  \left( x+75 \right)  \left( x-75
 \right) }}}
$

solving the equation $A'(x)=0$ we get

$x=25\,\sqrt {5}$

inserting nthis in the second derivative we obtain

$A''(x)=3/2\,{\frac {{x}^{6}-9375\,{x}^{4}+10546875\,{x}^{2}-10986328125}{
 \left( - \left( x+25 \right)  \left( x-25 \right)  \left( x+75
 \right)  \left( x-75 \right)  \right) ^{3/2}}}
$

$A''(25\sqrt{5})=-\frac{15}{4}<0$ and we get a maximum, the maximal area of the triangle is in this case given by $1875$.

Sonnhard.
rewritten_problem: One side of a triangle has length $75$.  Of the other two sides, the length of one is double the length of the other.  What is the maximum possible area for this triangle

text: Find the least positive integer $n$ such that the decimal representation of the binomial coefficient $\dbinom{2n}{n}$ ends in four zero digits.
title: Purple Comet 2008 HS Problem 20
solution:
Y by Math1331Math, Adventure10, Mango247, and 1 other usernot quite solution, but an estimationIt is about counting $5's$ for $1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 ... ... n$  and $ (n+1) \cdot (n+2) \cdot (n+3) ... ... 2n$.



It is all matters whether the numerator has extra $5's$.  Those can be only found at the end.

There is a pattern that is easy to find:



The closest to accomodate $5^1$ for $2n$ is $6$. $ {6 \choose 3}$  ends with 1 zero digits.

The closest to accomodate $5^2$ for $2n$ is $26$. $ {26 \choose 13}$  ends with 2 zero digits.

The closest to accomodate $5^3$ for $2n$ is $126$. $ {126 \choose 63}$  ends with 3 zero digits.

The closest to accomodate $5^4$ for $2n$ is $626$. $ {626 \choose  313}$  ends with 4 zero digits.



There we found $n=\boxed{313}$.
rewritten_problem: Find the least positive integer $n$ such that the decimal representation of the binomial coefficient $\dbinom{2n}{n}$ ends in four zero digits.

text: How many numbers $n$ have the property that both $\frac{n}{2}$ and $2n$ are four digits whole numbers?
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 2
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionStart with the lowest:

1000 is smallest 4-digit integer

9999 is largest 4-digit integer



$1000*2=2000$



$9999/2=4999.5=4999$



$4999-2000+1=$ $\boxed{3000}$

text: Square $ABCD$ has side length $36$.  Point $E$ is on side $AB$ a distance $12$ from $B$, point $F$ is the midpoint of side $BC$, and point $G$ is on side $CD$ a distance $12$ from $C$.  Find the area of the region that lies inside triangle $EFG$ and outside triangle $AFD$.
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 3
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionHere are some lengths that we will need to know:



$AB=BC=DC=DA=36$



$AE=DG=24$, $EB=CG=12$, $BF=FC=18$



Triangle $EFG$ has base $36$ and height $12$, therefore the answer is $36*12*0.5=36*6=216$



The overlapped triangle is similar to the triangle $AFD$. Because the height is $18$ and is $1/2$ of the larger triangle, the base is $0.5*36=18$



$18*18*0.5=162$



$216-162=$ $\boxed{54}$
rewritten_problem: Square $ABCD$ has side length $36$.  Point $E$ is on side $AB$ a distance $12$ from $B$, point $F$ is the midpoint of side $BC$, and point $G$ is on side $CD$ a distance $12$ from $C$.  Find the area of the region that lies inside triangle $EFG$ and outside triangle $AFD$.

text: Terry drove along a scenic road using $9$ gallons of gasoline.  Then Terry went onto the freeway and used $17$ gallons of gasoline.  Assuming that Terry gets $6.5$ miles per gallon better gas mileage on the freeway than on the scenic road, and Terrys average gas mileage for the entire trip was $30$ miles per gallon, find the number of miles Terry drove.
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 4
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionThere is a lot of extra information. The 6.5 miles per gallon is unnecessary.



So:



Your gas mileage is equvilant to $\frac{\text{miles}}{\text{gallons}}$ of gas.

Since the average gas mileage for the entire trip was 30 miles per gallon, $\frac{\text{Miles}}{\text{Gallons of gas}}=30$



The total amount of gas we used was $9+17=26$



Therefore we get that $miles/26=30$



Therefore, we drove $\boxed{780}$ miles.
rewritten_problem: Terry drove along a scenic road using $9$ gallons of gasoline.  Then Terry went onto the freeway and used $17$ gallons of gasoline.  Assuming that Terry gets $6.5$ miles per gallon better gas mileage on the freeway than on the scenic road, and Terrys average gas mileage for the entire trip was $30$ miles per gallon, find the number of miles Terry drove.

text: The product of two positive numbers is equal to $50$ times their sum and $75$ times their difference.  Find their sum.
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 6
solution:
Y by Adventure10SolutionWe have

\[mn=50(m+n)\]

\[mn=75(m-n)\]

Multiplying the top by 3, and the bottom 2:

\[3mn=150m+150n\]

\[2mn=150m-150n\]

Canceling:

\[5mn=300m\]

Dividing:

\[n=60\]

Substituting,

\[120m=150m-9000\]

\[30m=9000\]

\[m=300\]

\[m+n=\boxed{360}\]
rewritten_problem: The product of two positive numbers is equal to $50$ times their sum and $75$ times their difference.  Find their sum.

text: There is an interval $[a, b]$ that is the solution to the inequality \[|3x-80|\le|2x-105|\]  Find $a + b$.
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 7
solution:
Y by Adventure10My Solution$0\leq |3x-80|\leq |2x-105|\Longleftrightarrow|3x-80|^2\leq |2x-105|^2 $



$\Longleftrightarrow \{(3x-80)-(2x-105)\}\{(3x-80)+(2x-105)\}\leq 0$



$\Longleftrightarrow (x+25)(x-37)\leq 0$



$\therefore -25\leq x\leq 37$, yielding $a+b=-25+37=\boxed{12}$
rewritten_problem: There is an interval $[a, b]$ that is the solution to the inequality \[|3x-80|\le|2x-105|\]  Find $a + b$.

text: Penelope plays a game where she adds $25$ points to her score each time she wins a game and deducts $13$ points from her score each time she loses a game.  Starting with a score of zero, Penelope plays $m$ games and has a total score of $2007$ points.  What is the smallest possible value for $m$?
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 8
solution:
Y by Adventure10SolutionTry doing the smallest integer greater than $2007$ that is divisible by $25$, that would be $2025$



$2025-13=2007$, so he added $2025/25=81$ times and deducted $1$ times.



$81+1=$ $\boxed{82}$

text: Purple College keeps a careful count of its students as they progress each year from the freshman class to the sophomore class to the junior class and, finally, to the senior class.  Each year at the college one third of the freshman class drops out of school, $40$ students in the sophomore class drop out of school, and one tenth of the junior class drops out of school.  Given that the college only admits new freshman students, and that it wants to begin each school year with $3400$ students enrolled, how many students does it need to admit into the freshman class each year?
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 9
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247SolutionWe want 3400 students at the end of the junior class.  Since one tenth of the junior class drops out, we have the beginning junior class to be $\left\lceil\frac{10\times 3400}{9}\right\rceil=3778$.



40 students drop out of the sophmore class therefore we want to start with $3778+40=3818$ students in the sophmore class.



Lastly, one third of the freshmen drop out therefore we want $\left\lceil\frac{4\times 3818}{3}\right\rceil=\boxed{5091}$.
rewritten_problem: Purple College keeps a careful count of its students as they progress each year from the freshman class to the sophomore class to the junior class and, finally, to the senior class.  Each year at the college one third of the freshman class drops out of school, $40$ students in the sophomore class drop out of school, and one tenth of the junior class drops out of school.  Given that the college only admits new freshman students, and that it wants to begin each school year with $3400$ students enrolled, how many students does it need to admit into the freshman class each year?

text: Tom can run to Beth's house in $63$ minutes.  Beth can run to Tom's house in $84$ minutes.  At noon Tom starts running from his house toward Beth's house while at the same time Beth starts running from her house toward Tom's house.  When they meet, they both run at Beth's speed back to Beth's house.  At how many minutes after noon will they arrive at Beth's house?
title: Purple Comet 2007 MS Problem 10
solution:
Y by Adventure10, Mango247Click to reveal hidden textTom runs at a rate of $\frac{1}{63}$ of the distance between the houses per minute, and Beth runs at a rate of $\frac{1}{84}$ of the distance between the houses per minute.

Therefore, the rate at which the distance between them decreases is $\frac{1}{63}+\frac{1}{84}=\frac{1}{36}$ of the distance between the houses per minute. It follows that it takes $36$ minutes for them to meet. Running back at Beth's speed back to Beth's house takes another $36$ minutes, so they will arrive at Beth's house $36+36=\boxed{72}$ minutes after noon.
rewritten_problem: Tom can run to Beth's house in $63$ minutes.  Beth can run to Tom's house in $84$ minutes.  At noon Tom starts running from his house toward Beth's house while at the same time Beth starts running from her house toward Tom's house.  When they meet, they both run at Beth's speed back to Beth's house.  At how many minutes after noon will they arrive at Beth's house?

If we apply the same permutation to $T_1$, we get $T_2$ which is $\text{ZGYKTEJMUXSODVLIAHNFPWRQCB}$.  We continually apply this permutation to each $T_m$ to get $T_{m+1}$.  Find the smallest positive integer $n$ so that $T_n=T_0$.
